what I like to hear.

We have a wonderful,

is a random photo of my baby. But I was just,

I would share, which is really not
the important thing.

Though, maybe the important
thing is, it's a Friday, so I like to start Fridays with

And the story I was

at six. Again, this morning

it's a fun way to

going to tell you guys today was actually an interesting
story from my own life.

You guys may or
may not know this, but I am legally
blind in one eye. And the story behind that
is quite interesting.

When I was 11 years old, I was
living in Kenya at the time, and I believe I
was with my parents

and they were like pointing
something out, and I was like, should I look out of my
good eye or my bad eye? And my parents are like, what?

[LAUGHTER] Like, you're not supposed to
have a good eye and a bad eye. I thought everyone had one. [LAUGHTER] And so, I was like, yeah, I
can't see out my left eye.

And they were like, we
should actually probably look into that. And long story short, something
happened to my left eye.

It was a disease, and not
contagious, don't worry. But the thing that
happened to my left eye

was going to happen
to my right eye. And eventually, a
doctor in Nairobi figured out exactly what it
was, and and they figured out

how to get me the solution. It was a little
late for my left eye though, because it had
been bad for a long time. But then at one
point, my vision,

my right eye went as well. But because this
doctor had figured out what had gone wrong, they
gave me the solution.

Which is an injection to the
eye, which is not the most fun thing, but, you know, I
get to see because of it. He was able to give me that
solution exactly when I

needed it. So I was able to keep
vision in my right eye. And I can see just 20/20
out of my right eye.

And on some level-- and the left eye
continues to be a pain. Because it's been so long
without being treated,

it just like causes-- it's my problem child eye. And despite the fact that
this has been something

I've had to deal with my
entire life, and of course, it probably be more fun
to see out of both eyes, and there's always the
risk that I will go blind,

it has been the most wonderful
silver lining in my life, and I don't know how to express
it, but I'm going to try.

There is something about
being a middle schooler, where it's hard to
appreciate life. Like, you're just like,
middle school is hard.

But I had this weird
experience at middle school where I was like,
whoa, I'm supposed to not be able to have one
of these primary senses,

and yet I do. And so I had this appreciation
that was a big part of my life

when there's a lot about middle
school not to appreciate. And then there's other silver
linings that have come from it.

I certainly feel like I relate
to a lot of things much better, and a really small silver
lining is I came to Stanford.

And of course, there's
doctors helping me to make sure it doesn't
happen to my right eye and to keep track
of the left eye. And there was this time
when this doctor was

about to do a surgery on my eye,

what do you study? I'm like, I study
artificial intelligence.
